docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 3 MOTION OR PROCEEDINGS FOR PUNISHMENT [rr 5–11]

heading.title: DIVISION 3 MOTION OR PROCEEDINGS FOR PUNISHMENT [rr 5–11]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 3 MOTION OR PROCEEDINGS FOR PUNISHMENT [rr 5–11]

p.text: This Division does not apply to a case in which the Court proceeds under Division 2 .
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.5.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Div 3, rr 2, 3, 4, rule.

This rule makes it clear that the formal requirements of Div 3 do not apply to proceedings for contempt in the face of the court, which are dealt with under rr 2 , 3 and 4 : Registrar, Court of Appeal v Collins [1982] 1 NSWLR 682 at 700 .

Where contempt is committed in connection with proceedings in the Court, an application for punishment for the contempt must be made by motion on notice in the proceedings, but, if separate proceedings for punishment of the contempt are commenced, the proceedings so commenced may be continued unless the Court otherwise orders.

Where contempt is committed, but not in connection with proceedings in the Court, proceedings for punishment of the contempt must be commenced by summons, but, if an application for punishment of the contempt is made by motion on notice in any proceedings, the application may be heard and disposed of in the latter proceedings, unless the Court otherwise orders.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.6.1] Persons who may commence contempt proceedings

heading.title: Persons who may commence contempt proceedings

p.text: Any person has the right to bring an action for contempt in relation to proceedings in a court where that person has a personal stake or special interest in the proceedings: United Telecasters Sydney Ltd v Hardy (1991) 23 NSWLR 323 at 328 ; European Asian Bank AG v Wentworth (1986) 5 NSWLR 445 at 460 ; Varley v A-G (NSW) (1987) 8 NSWLR 30 at 36–7 . Where the alleged contempt involves publication of material prejudicial to the fair trial of criminal proceedings it is usual practice for that charge to be heard after the conclusion of the related criminal proceedings: Attorney-General (NSW) v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 402 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.6.1A] Commencement of proceedings against third persons

heading.title: Commencement of proceedings against third persons

p.text: Despite the language of the rule, the view has been expressed that proceedings for contempt ought not be brought against non parties by motion in the principal proceedings: Abram v National Australia Bank Ltd (NSWCA, Mason P, Priestley and Powell JJA, No 40487/94, unreported, BC9701553) per Powell JA; Harkianakis v Skalkos (1997) 42 NSWLR 22 at 69 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.6.2] Summary proceedings

p.text: Summary proceedings are the proper mode of prosecuting criminal contempt. Trial on indictment is obsolete: Re Colina; Ex parte Torney (1999) 200 CLR 386; 166 ALR 545 ; United Telecasters Sydney Ltd v Hardy (1991) 23 NSWLR 323 at 330 . Similarly, there is no jury trial in contempt proceedings: Witham v Holloway (1995) 183 CLR 525 at 534; 131 ALR 401; [1995] HCA 3; BC9506443 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.6.3] Publication of the identity of contemnor

heading.title: Publication of the identity of contemnor

p.text: The Supreme Court has power to forbid publication of the name of an alleged contemnor, though the occasions for the exercise of the power will be rare: Raybos Australia Pty Ltd v Jones (1985) 2 NSWLR 47 at 53, 63 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.6.4] Injunction to restrain contempt

p.text: The court has power to grant an injunction to restrain threatened contempt: New South Wales Bar Assn v Muirhead (1988) 14 NSWLR 173 . However, the appropriateness of such a restraining order will inevitably depend on the circumstances of the particular case. For example, the court may issue an injunction to restrain a witness from leaving the jurisdiction to avoid complying with a subpoena: Patton v Australian Consolidated Press (NSWCA, Full Court, 12 October 1989, unreported). But an injunction to restrain an alleged contempt that involves the publication of material alleged to be likely to interfere with the fair trial of proceedings will require consideration of the nature of the proceedings. It will rarely be appropriate to restrain publication where it relates to civil proceedings being heard by a judge alone — because it is unlikely that the determination of the proceedings could be influenced by the publication: Waterhouse v Australian Broadcasting Corp (1986) 6 NSWLR 733 ; Civil Aviation Authority v Australian Broadcasting Corp (1995) 39 NSWLR 540 (coronial inquest).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55 r 7] r 7 Statement of charge

p.text: A statement of charge, that is, a statement specifying the contempt of which the contemnor is alleged to be guilty, shall be subscribed to, or filed with, the notice of motion or summons.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.7.0] Priority over UCP Rules

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.7.0] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 1.7, Sch 2.
UCP r 1.7 and Sch 2 provide that SCR Pt 55 r 7 prevails notwithstanding any inconsistency with provisions of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.7.1] Sufficiency of statement of charge

p.text: The statement of charge must clearly identify the precise conduct alleged to constitute contempt: Harmsworth v Harmsworth [1987] 3 All ER 816; [1987] 1 WLR 1676 at 1683; [1988] Fam Law 169; [1988] 1 Fam Law R 349 ; McDonnell v Novello [2006] NSWSC 1186; BC200609199 at [26]. The purpose of a statement of charge is to provide the person concerned with due notice, and a proper opportunity to answer the charge: see Coward v Stapleton (1953) 90 CLR 573 at 579–80; [1953] ALR 743; (1953) 27 ALJR 423; BC5301000 ; Inghams Enterprises Pty Ltd v Timania Pty Ltd (2005) 221 ALR 823; [2005] FCAFC 155; BC200506146 at [32]; and see [SCR Pt 55.3.1] . Unless and until they are amended, the particulars of the charge limit the scope of the matters able to be considered: see Construction, Forestry, Mining & Energy Union v BHP Steel (AIS) Pty Ltd [2001] FCA 1758; BC200108914 at [30]–[32].

As a general proposition, intentional disobedience or impropriety is not necessary to establish a charge of contempt: Ainsworth v Hanrahan (1991) 25 NSWLR 155 at 168E; Pang v Bydand Holdings Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 69; BC201101944 at [52]–[54]. But the alleged contemnor’s knowledge or belief may be material in establishing whether their conduct was relevantly improper: see (the unusual facts relied on in) Ditfort v Brown (1990) 19 NSWLR 49 ; Ditfort v Katz (NSWCA, Full Court, 8 July 1991, unreported, BC9101811) (ambiguous assertion that the contemnor made a “false” statement — no particulars of dishonesty). If the charge involves an allegation of deliberate defiance of a court order (ie criminal contempt) the conduct relied on should be particularised in the charge: Tweed Shire Council v Mannix (1983) 50 LGRA 369 at 375; Mosman Municipal Council v Kelly (No 3) (2009) 167 LGERA 91; [2009] NSWLEC 92; BC200905332 at [83]–[84].

Where inaction is the contempt alleged, for example, in failing to perform an ordered act, the required particulars are likely to be brief. Where the contempt alleged involves conduct in contravention of a prohibition, especially a limited or conditional prohibition, then the statement of charge must identify the precise acts that are said to constitute the contravention of the court’s order: McDonnell v Novello, above (limited conditional restraint from entering property — statement of charge must include circumstances of entry and conduct undertaken after entry) .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.7.2] “Subcribed to, or filed with”

p.text: A statement of charge may be contained in the same document or paper as the summons or notice of motion (“subscribed to”) or it may be in a separate document accompanying the notice of motion (“filed with”). It is not sufficient for the two documents to be filed separately and distinctly: McDonnell v Novello [2006] NSWSC 1186; BC200609199 at [13] (statement of charge filed six days after the filing of the notice of motion)
Subject to subrule (2) , the evidence in support of the charge shall be by affidavit.
The Court may, on terms, permit evidence in support of the charge to be given otherwise than by affidavit.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.1] Contempt — disclosure of information acquired for the purpose of proceedings

heading.title: Contempt — disclosure of information acquired for the purpose of proceedings

p.text: A party commits a contempt of court by providing answers to interrogatories to a third party for purposes extraneous to the proceedings in which the answers were given: Ainsworth v Hanrahan (1991) 25 NSWLR 155 . See also [21.7.5] dealing with the implied undertaking in relation to documents obtained on discovery.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.2] Contempt — disclosure of confidential information

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.8.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 [s 72.25].

The publication of information relating to court proceedings conducted in private, such as wardship proceedings, may amount to contempt of court: P v P (1985) 2 NSWLR 401 at 403; 10 Fam LR 315 . See also [s 72.25] .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.4] Publication of matters relating to pending proceedings — “sub judice”

heading.title: Publication of matters relating to pending proceedings — “sub judice”

p.text: Publication of matters connected with pending but undetermined judicial proceedings: James v Robinson (1963) 109 CLR 593; [1964] ALR 7 ; may constitute contempt of court. The importance of maintaining both the actual and reputed fairness and impartiality of the judicial process imposes significant limitations on the public discussion of pending proceedings, particularly criminal proceedings. Those limitations impose some well recognised limitations on the publication of the prejudicial information about accused persons, substantive information about the circumstances of the alleged offence, and opinions about the outcome: see generally Halsbury’s Law of Australia, “Contempt” para [105-75]. But, underlying these limitations are competing public interests, which may require careful resolution in particular cases. One such interest is that of the parties, and the public, in the fair trial of proceedings. Another is the public interest in free discussion of matters of public concern. The criterion for determining whether material published following the laying of criminal charges constitutes contempt is whether, as a matter of practical reality, the material has real and definite bearing on the guilt or innocence of a specific person in relation to a specific charge: Attorney-General (NSW) v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1985) 6 NSWLR 695 ; Attorney-General (NSW) v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (1990) 20 NSWLR 368 ; Attorney-General (NSW) v Dean (1990) 20 NSWLR 650; 50 A Crim R 342 ; Attorney-General (NSW) v Mundey [1972] 2 NSWLR 887 ; James v Robinson , above, CLR at 602. In relation to civil proceedings, a publication will amount to contempt if it has the tendency of deterring a litigant from pursuing the proceedings, either by disparagement because they are a party, or because of the nature of the litigation and the issues that arise in it: Hinch v A-G (Vic) (1987) 164 CLR 15 at 54; 74 ALR 353 ; Harkianakis v Skalkos (1997) 42 NSWLR 22 . It will also constitute contempt if it tends to influence, or deter, witnesses: Attorney-General (UK) v Times Newspapers Ltd [1974] AC 273; [1973] 3 All ER 54 ; Gregory v Phillip Morris (1987) 74 ALR 300 ; Victoria v Australian Building Construction Employees' and Builders' Labourers' Federation (1982) 152 CLR 25 at 58–9; 41 ALR 71 . If the publication is not likely either to deter the continuation of the litigation, or affect its proper determination, the publication, even of actionable defamatory statements concerning a litigant, will not constitute contempt: Harkianakis v Skalkos , above. And in determining the likely effect of the publication on the proceedings, it is proper to regard it as unlikely to affect the determinations of a judicial officer, as distinct from its possible effect on the conduct of a jury or witnesses: Waterhouse v Australian Broadcasting Corp (1986) 6 NSWLR 733 ; Civil Aviation Authority v Australian Broadcasting Corp (1995) 39 NSWLR 540 (coronial inquest); Victoria v Australian Building Construction Employees' and Builders' Labourers' Federation , above, CLR at 57. If the publication offends these principles, the publication may constitute contempt, notwithstanding the implied constitutional protection of free communication: John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v Doe (1995) 37 NSWLR 81 at 109–110. However, where the publication of the alleged contempt involves public discussion, it will be a defence if the court is satisfied that the public interest in the freedom of communication outweighs any detriment to the trial of the proceedings: Hinch v A-G (Vic) , above, CLR at 52; Attorney-General (NSW) v X (2000) 49 NSWLR 653; [2000] NSWCA 199; BC200004289 ; Re Truth and Sportsman Ltd; Ex parte Bread Manufacturers Ltd (1937) 37 SR (NSW) 242 ; Registrar, Court of Appeal v Willesee (1985) 3 NSWLR 650 (defence applies to criminal proceedings).

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.4A] Failure to comply with orders

p.text: Disobedience to court orders typically constitutes a contempt that is characterised as civil contempt: Australasian Meat Industry Employees' Union v Mudginberri Station Pty Ltd (1986) 161 CLR 98; 66 ALR 577; BC8601455 ; Australian Building Construction Employees' and Builders' Labourers' Federation v David Syme & Co Ltd (1982) 40 ALR 518; 59 FLR 48 ; Witham v Holloway (1995) 183 CLR 525 at 530; 131 ALR 401; [1995] HCA 3; BC9506443 . The disobedience is a contempt even if the order of a superior court was made without jurisdiction: Matthews v Australian Securities & Investments Commission (2000) 97 FCR 396; 170 ALR 149; [2000] FCA 288; BC200001037 ; contrast Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 . Deliberate defiance of a court order may constitute criminal contempt: Australasian Meat Industry Employees' Union v Mudginberri Station Pty Ltd (1986) 161 CLR 98; 66 ALR 577; BC8601455, above,CLR at 108 ; Witham v Holloway, above, CLR at 530 ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Reid (No 2) [2006] FCA 700; BC200604118 at [18] (two previous contempt findings — prior custodial sentence suspended — further non compliance with same order — wilful and contumacious disobedience).

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.4B] Failure to comply with ambiguous order

heading.title: Failure to comply with ambiguous order

p.text: An order cannot be enforced by contempt proceedings if it is so ambiguous that the person otherwise required to obey it was in real doubt about what obedience involved: Australian Consolidated Press Ltd v Morgan (1965) 112 CLR 483 at 515, 516; [1966] ALR 387; BC6500220 ; Kirkpatrick v Kotis (2004) 62 NSWLR 567; [2004] NSWSC 1265; BC200409031 at [55] ; Microsoft Corporation & Microsoft Pty Ltd v Marks (1996) 69 FCR 117 at 143; 139 ALR 99; BC9604091 . That criterion must, however, be taken to assume that the person affected makes a genuine attempt to understand and comply with the order. And in that regard, it is proper to take into account the surrounding circumstances in order to determine whether the order conveys a particular meaning or is genuinely ambiguous: Kirkpatrick v Kotis, above, at [38]–[45] .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.5] Misconduct related to the conduct of proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Jury Act 1977 s 68B.

heading.title: Misconduct related to the conduct of proceedings

p.text: Interference with the conduct of proceedings may result from, but is not confined to, misconduct that occurs “in the face … or … hearing of the Court” (as to which see [SCR Pt 55.2.1] ). Private communications with a judicial officer provide the most obvious example of conduct that occurs away from the public venue of the hearing and yet may constitute contempt: Re JRL; Ex parte CJL (1986) 161 CLR 342 at 347; 66 ALR 239 . Similarly, pursuing proceedings in order to achieve a collateral purpose may constitute contempt: Rajski v Bainton (1990) 22 NSWLR 125 at 132; BC9001557 . It is a serious interference with the administration of justice to attempt to influence or obstruct a witness, remove a witness from the jurisdiction, or to sanction them for having given evidence: Watson v Collings (1944) 70 CLR 51 at 58; [1945] ALR 178 ; Lane v Registrar, Supreme Court of New South Wales (1981) 148 CLR 245 at 257; 35 ALR 322 ; Re Goldman [1968] 3 NSWR 325 at 327–8; (1968) 89 WN Pt 1 (NSW) 175 ; Farahbakht v Midas Australia Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1322; BC200610117 at [41]–[42] per Brereton J, 30 October 2006 (a telephone conversation with the deponent of an affidavit with the intention of raising of some, perhaps slight, pressure, influence or encouragement not to tell the whole truth and to either to decline to give evidence, or to give evidence in a way which would not hurt the party and his family). Attempts to interfere with, or sanction, jurors also constitutes contempt: Re Dunn [1906] VLR 493 ; Prothonotary v Collins (1985) 2 NSWLR 549 ; R v Loveday; Ex parte Medcalf [1982] WAR 65; (1981) 5 A Crim R 197 . (It is less clear that disclosure of the contents of jury room discussions is necessarily contempt: Attorney-General (UK) v Associated Newspapers [1994] 2 AC 238; [1994] 1 All ER 556 ; Attorney-General v New Statesman and Nation Publishing Co Ltd [1981] QB 1; [1980] 1 All ER 644 ; though it will breach s 68B of the Jury Act 1977 if it is done for reward). Obstructing a party in the conduct of proceedings, as distinct from attempting to influence them not to pursue proceedings, constitutes contempt: Attorney-General (UK) v Times Newspapers Ltd [1974] AC 273 at 313, 317–19; [1973] 3 All ER 54 . So too does a reprisal against a successful party: Clarkson v Mandarin Club Ltd (1998) 90 FCR 354; BC9807046 .) Similarly, interference with the service of court process, including a subpoena, constitutes contempt: Re Barnes [1968] 1 NSWR 697; (1968) 87 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 479 . A failure to comply with the terms of a properly served subpoena also constitutes contempt of court: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Maniam (No 1) (1991) 25 NSWLR 459 ; Lane v Registrar, Supreme Court of New South Wales , above, CLR at 257. It is less clear that disclosure of the contents of jury room discussions is not necessarily contempt: Attorney-General (UK) v Associated Newspapers , above; Attorney-General v New Statesman and Nation Publishing Co Ltd , above.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.5A] Misconduct towards, and by, legal practitioners

heading.title: Misconduct towards, and by, legal practitioners

p.text: Abuse or threats or an assault upon a legal advisor by a party to the litigation will constitute contempt when the conduct has a tendency to interfere with the course of justice: Re Goldman [1968] 3 NSWR 325 at 327–8; (1968) 89 WN Pt 1 (NSW) 175 ; Principal Registrar, Supreme Court of New South Wales v Katelaris [2001] NSWSC 506; BC200103328 (litigant in person intentionally hit counsel for opposing party with folded copy of judgment). A more difficult question is the extent to which a party is liable for misconduct by their legal representative. If the conduct has been expressly authorised by the client, liability may attach in accordance with ordinary agency principles. However, where the misconduct results from a mere omission by the legal practitioner, the client is not answerable to a charge of contempt: Forestview Nominees Pty Ltd v Perron Investments Pty Ltd (1999) 93 FCR 117; 162 ALR 482 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.6] Liquidators, receivers, bailiffs

p.text: Interference with or obstruction of a liquidator or receiver appointed by the court may amount to a contempt of court: McIntyre v Perkes (1988) 15 NSWLR 417; Re Joshua Stubbs Ltd; Barney v Joshua Stubbs Ltd [1891] 1 Ch 475 . In such circumstances the court may require the contemnor to make good to the receiver the loss or expense occasioned by the contempt: McIntyre v Perkes , above. It is also contempt to interfere with persons executing court process, including persons seeking to execute orders and judgments of the court: Lewis v Owen [1894] 1 QB 102 ; Alliance Building Society v Austen [1951] 2 All ER 1068 (re-taking possession of land after eviction by writ of possession); Re Murphy (1927) 27 SR (NSW) 503; 44 WN (NSW) 189 (re-taking possession of seized goods).

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.6A] Contempt arising from misconduct by non-parties

heading.title: Contempt arising from misconduct by non-parties

p.text: It is implicit in the immediately preceding annotations that misconduct by strangers to the litigation may constitute contempt. A person who knowingly acts in a way that will frustrate the operation of a court order is guilty of contempt even though the order is not directed to them and even though they did not directly assist in its breach: Attorney-General (UK) v Times Newspapers Ltd [1992] 1 AC 191; [1991] 2 All ER 398 ; Z Ltd v A-Z [1982] QB 558; [1982] 1 All ER 556 ; Grant-Taylor v Jamieson (2002) 11 BPR 21,023; [2002] NSWSC 634; BC200203967 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.7] Misconduct involving abuse of process or collateral purposes

heading.title: Misconduct involving abuse of process or collateral purposes

p.text: A contempt of court may be committed by a party taking steps to bring about a result which it had failed to achieve or could not achieve by a proper exercise of the court's powers: Argyle Art Centre Pty Ltd v Argyle Bond & Free Stores Co Pty Ltd [1976] 1 NSWLR 377 (landlord issued two notices to quit, commenced proceedings in respect of the first notice and proceeded pursuant to the second notice whilst the proceedings in respect of the first notice were pending); Brambles Holdings Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (No 2) (1980) 32 ALR 328; 44 FLR 182 at 192 (service of a notice for the purpose of obtaining information which could not be obtained by discovery or interrogatories); Howse Fink & Johnson Computing Services Pty Ltd v Beard (NSWSC, Powell J, No 1841/89, 26 October 1989, unreported, BC8901536) (deliberate default by lessor causing repossession by finance company of motor vehicle in possession of lessee whilst proceedings pending between lessor and lessee as to entitlement to possession of motor vehicle).

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.8] Failure to comply with contractual agreement noted by court

heading.title: Failure to comply with contractual agreement noted by court

p.text: It is not a contempt of court where a party fails to honour an agreement, the terms of which have merely been noted by the court in the course of the proceedings: Eagle Star Trustees Ltd v Tai Ping Trading Pty Ltd (No 2) (NSWSC, Young J, 30 October 1990, unreported, BC9001811). Neither is it a contempt to disclose terms of settlement if the judge has merely noted “terms not to be disclosed”: S Hoffnung & Co Ltd v Hesky [1977] 2 NSWLR 669 ; cf National Bank of Australasia Ltd v Solar (1977) 14 ACTR 1; 28 FLR 372 . The contractual agreement between the parties that the terms should not be disclosed does not give rise to a breach of the agreement if disclosure occurs in accordance with the requirements of discovery or in answer to a subpoena: State Rail Authority of New South Wales v Smith (1998) 45 NSWLR 382; BC9806784 citing Nestle Australia Ltd v FCT (1986) 11 FCR 453; 67 ALR 128 . As to the enforcement of undertakings to the court, see [40.6.15] .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.9] Seizure of documents

p.text: The seizure of documents in the possession of a defendant during the course of committal proceedings, in circumstances where a search warrant had not first been obtained, was not contempt of court: Rowell v Larter (1986) 6 NSWLR 21 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.8.10] Criticism of judicial officers

p.text: Allegations about a judge's supposed partiality, impropriety, improper motive and the like may constitute contempt: R v Dunbabin; Ex parte Williams (1935) 53 CLR 434; [1935] ALR 232 (article disparaging the High Court); Gallagher v Durack (1983) 152 CLR 238; 45 ALR 53 ; Re Goodwin; Ex parte A-G (1969) 70 SR (NSW) 413; 91 WN (NSW) 29 ; Attorney-General (NSW) v Mundey [1972] 2 NSWLR 887 ; Bainton v Rajski (1992) 29 NSWLR 539 at 542 . For example, statements by a legal practitioner calculated to impair public confidence in a judicial officer carrying the risk of publication and undermining public confidence in the administration of justice fulfil the criteria for contempt: Attorney-General (Qld) v Lovitt [2003] QSC 279; BC200305006 (counsel alleged to have referred to presiding magistrate as a complete cretin in court in hearing of members of the press). However the context, terms and purpose of the comments must be taken into account. Even forceful comments about the perceived partiality or competence of a judicial officer, where they have a legitimate forensic purpose, do not constitute contempt, despite the personal affront to which they may give rise: Lewis v Ogden (1984) 153 CLR 682; 53 ALR 53 ; Murphy v Magistrates' Court at Prahran (1995) 80 A Crim R 92; BC9503911 (complaint of bias not contempt); Parashuram Deteram Shamdasani v King-Emperor [1945] AC 264; (1945) 61 TLR 448 .
The notice of motion or summons, the statement of charge, and the affidavits shall be served personally on the contemnor.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.9.5] Personal service

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.21.

Since the repeal of SCR Pt 9 r 3(2) there is no definition of the concept of “personal service” in the SCR. The concept should be understood in light of UCPR, in particular r 10.21 : McDonnell v Novello [2006] NSWSC 1186; BC200609199 at [15] (notice of motion faxed to plaintiff’s solicitor, copy of statement of charge sent by post to solicitor’s post office box — not served personally subject to the possibility that this requirement may have been dispensed with in the orders).

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.9.10] Personal service of court order

p.text: Judgments requiring, or proscribing, particular conduct cannot be enforced unless the person affected has been served with a copy of the order: UCPR r 40.7. But, apart from such a situation, there is no formal requirement for personal service of any court order relied on to make out a charge of contempt. And whilst the alleged contemnor’s knowledge of the relevant order will be necessary to establish, unless the matter is one of merely “technical” (ie “inadvertent”) conduct, that knowledge may be sufficiently established without evidence of formal service: Gerondal v Eurobodalla Shire Council (No 5) [2011] NSWLEC 104; BC201104841 at [45] (repeated attempts at personal service — contemnor aware of the order).
Where:
notice of a motion for punishment of a contempt has been filed or proceedings have been commenced for punishment of a contempt, and
it appears to the Court that the contemnor is likely to abscond or otherwise withdraw himself from the jurisdiction of the Court,

the Court may issue a warrant for the arrest of the contemnor and his detention in custody until he is brought before the Court to answer the charge, unless he, in the meantime, gives security in such manner and in such sum as the Court directs, for his appearance in person to answer the charge and to submit to the judgment or order of the Court.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.10.1] Arrest of alleged contemnor

p.text: Even apart from the present rule, the court has power to order the arrest of an alleged contemnor to secure their attendance to answer a contempt charge: Registrar, Court of Appeal v Ritter (1985) 34 NSWLR 641 ; Attorney-General v Hayden (1994) 34 NSWLR 638 . The present rule confers an additional power to arrest an alleged contemnor against whom proceedings have been commenced and where the court is satisfied they are likely to “abscond” or “withdraw”. Exercise of the power under this rule is only justified where the court is satisfied the rule applies, and that satisfaction will require careful attention to the particular requirements of the rule: Patton v Harrison (No 1) (NSWCA, Full Court, 12 October 1989, unreported). The likelihood of absconding or withdrawal is to be determined on the balance of probabilities: Schnabel v Lui (2002) 56 NSWLR 119; [2002] NSWSC 1184; BC200208087 at [15] . Absconding and withdrawal are alternatives. Absconding connotes the contemnor’s purpose of avoiding the contempt proceedings by leaving the jurisdiction of the court. Withdrawing from the jurisdiction merely refers to a prolonged absence, irrespective of the alleged contemnor’s purpose: Schnabel v Lui , above, at [18].

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.10.2] Security

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.10.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 55 r 10.

A warrant for arrest should provide for the alternative provision of security by the alleged contemnor: Schnabel v Lui (2002) 56 NSWLR 119; [2002] NSWSC 1184; BC200208087 at [12] . In Patton v Harrison (No 1) (NSWCA, Full Court, 12 October 1989, unreported) the Court of Appeal ordered that the amount of the security referred to in Pt 55 r 10 be set at $50,000. But this alternative will be inappropriate where the circumstances indicate the likelihood of the alleged contemnor absconding if released from custody: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Michalik (No 2) (2004) 62 NSWLR 335; 52 ACSR 115; [2004] NSWSC 1260; BC200409028 (defendants arrested trying to leave Australia in breach of court order).

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.10.3] Procedure for detention in custody of alleged contemnor

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.10.3] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Pt 55 r 10.

heading.title: Procedure for detention in custody of alleged contemnor

p.text: Ordinarily an alleged contemnor will not be placed in custody, unless there is a real risk the person will abscond. The Supreme Court Rules do not provide a procedure for the interim custodial detention in custody of an alleged contemnor arrested under Pt 55 r 10 pending final hearing of the contempt charge. A person who is so arrested is a “person in custody” within the meaning of s 249 of the Crimes (Administration of Sentences) Act 1999. The procedures for detention set out in Pt 13 of that Act may therefore be followed in respect of the alleged contemnor pending final hearing of the contempt charge: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Michalik (No 2) (2004) 62 NSWLR 335; 52 ACSR 115; [2004] NSWSC 1260; BC200409028 at [40]–[43] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55 r 11] r 11 Motion or proceedings by the registrar

leg:heading.title: Motion or proceedings by the registrar

p.text: Where it is alleged, or appears to the Court on its own view, that a person is guilty of contempt of the Court or of any other court, the Court may, by order, direct the registrar to apply by motion for, or to commence proceedings for, punishment of the contempt.
Subrule (1) does not affect such right as any person other than the registrar may have to apply by motion for, or to commence proceedings for, punishment of contempt.
Where:
[repealed]

it appears to a Local Court on its own view that a person is guilty of contempt of the Local Court, whether during a proceeding before the Local Court or otherwise, and the court refers the matter to the Court for determination under section 27B of the Local Courts Act 1982,
the registrar must commence proceedings for punishment of the contempt, and no direction from the Court shall be necessary to enable the registrar to do so.
[subr (3) subst Amendment 268: Gaz 130 of 30 October 1992 p 7980 ; am Amendment 279: Gaz 104 of 24 September 1993 p 6025 ; Amendment 377: Gaz 132 of 29 August 2003 p 8934, effective 29 August 2003]

Subrule (3) does not affect such right as any person other than the registrar may have to commence proceedings for punishment of the contempt prior to the commencement of proceedings by the registrar.
[subr (4) insrt Amendment 256: Gaz 116 of 16 August 1991 p 6836]
Subrule (3) does not apply in the event that a person other than the registrar commences proceedings for punishment of the contempt prior to the commencement of proceedings by the registrar.
[subr (5) insrt Amendment 256: Gaz 116 of 16 August 1991 p 6836]

Subject to the rules and to any Act, where, pursuant to a power conferred by or under an Act, a court or other body or person refers or reports a matter to the Court with a view to the Court dealing with a possible contempt of the court, body or person, the registrar shall:
take advice from the Crown Solicitor as to whether the registrar should take proceedings for contempt in respect of the matter;
unless the Court otherwise orders, act in accordance with the advice; and
inform the Attorney-General of the matter.
[subr (6) insrt Amendment 318: Gaz 32 of 20 February 1998 p 843 ; am Amendment 331: Gaz 95 of 20 August 1999 p 6128]

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 55.11.1] Commencement of proceedings for contempt

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 55.11.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 203.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 s 24(4), 24(5).

The rule preserves the common law entitlement of private litigants to bring proceedings for contempt: R v Dunbabin; Ex parte Williams (1935) 53 CLR 434; [1935] ALR 232 ; Re Lucas; Ex parte Tubman [1970] 3 NSWR 41; (1970) 72 SR (NSW) 555 ; European Asian Bank AG v Wentworth (1986) 5 NSWLR 445 . But it does not confer on private litigants an additional right to apply for the court itself to commence and maintain proceedings for criminal contempt. The commencement of such proceedings by the registrar is entirely a matter for the court as a ministerial decision: Killen v Lane [1983] 1 NSWLR 171 . The rule permits the registrar to commence proceedings either by notice of motion or by commencing separate proceedings. (If the alleged contempt relates to proceedings in the Court of Appeal, the proceedings are assigned to that court: contrast Prothonotary v George (NSWCA, 25 July 1978, unreported, BC7800014). Referral of contempt matters under either District Court Act 1973 s 203 or Local Court Act 2007 s 24(4) , 24(5) requires the registrar to commence proceedings, subject to any contrary direction the court may give in the exercise of the discretion conferred by those statutory provisions. (If any such direction is given, the judge's report should be dealt with in open court, even though the ministerial character of the decision does not require the attendance of the alleged contemnor: see Re an Allegation by Judge Mathews (NSWCA, Full Court, 7 March 1984, unreported, BC8400372).

The registrar acts by virtue of the office. It is inappropriate to use the personal name of the registrar as a party: Kerr v Cmr of Police [1977] 2 NSWLR 721 at 724 ; Principal Registrar, Supreme Court of New South Wales v Katelaris [2001] NSWSC 506; BC200103328 .
